comment.narrative: The Poverty Reduction Strategy and Action Plan (PRSAP) projected 5% economic growth for the country to sustain upward human development, cemented on policies that provide for options that foster inclusiveness growth. National consultations to inform the development of the CPD 2016-2020 highlighted that the country has good policies, however implementation of these instrument does not translate to sustainable national development through economic growth. The intervention will support research, create dialogue space for development and nurturing of policy ideas leading to production advisory, technical briefs and dissemination. This will build further the necessary capacities for policy development/implementation through effective partnerships and tracking for policy impact.

1. Conduct 2 technical research and capacity needs assessment (with focus on high investment) for policy promulgating, and enrichment of monitoring and evaluation systems in the country. 2. Support 2 national informal and formal discussions (indaba) to enrich policy uptake and or operationalisation. 3. Facilitate technical support through advisory services to national entities: Ministry of Economic Planning and Development and the Ministry of Commence Industry and Trade.. 4. Develop 2 Policy or Technical Briefs for the various sectors. 5. Facilitate advisory and mentoring services for knowledge and skills translation including through South-South Cooperation for 2 areas of economic growth that have been prioritised by the country. 6. Build national public sector management capacities for planning, budgeting and policy monitoring.

1. Partnered with the Swaziland Economic Research Policy Analysis Centre (SERPAC) for policy research. Two (2) research studies were initiated namely: (i) “Socio-economic impact of disaster in Swaziland, and (ii) Governance through National Boards: An Investigation of Production and Consumer Welfare in Swaziland. Innovation application was enabled through the development of a research APP for the Swaziland Economic Research Policy Analysis Centre (SERPAC) to promote the interaction of researchers and information users and facilitate better research information dissemination (IRRF 7.6.1).
2. National discussions were enabled through two (2) dialogues: ‘Investment in Agriculture Symposium’ and the country-wide ‘Regional Waste Management Indaba’. The ‘Investment in Agriculture Symposium hosted through UNDP-SEPARC Partnerships led to transmission of the key message that food security can be improved through smart techniques that including integration of climate modelling information in planning while the Waste Management discussions shared information of community venturing in income-generating jobs through waste re-use and re-cycling interventions. 3. Advisory services and technical support was provided leading to the development of the draft Special Economic Zones Policy and Special Economic Zones Bill along development of options for economy diversification.
4. Two Policy Briefs were prepared and presented to the Minister of Natural Resources and Energy calling for the review of the National Water Policy and the development of the Special Economic Zones’ Policy. The draft Special Economic Zones Policy is in place while the review of the National Water Policy is underway (IRRF 7.3.1).
5. Support was not provided given financing resource limitations.
6. Supported participation of one individual from the ‘think tank’ institution SEPARC to the Africa Economic Conference 2016 “Feed Africa: Towards Agro-Allied Initialization for Inclusive Growth” hosted in Nigeria. Provided capacity building for: three (3) participants from the Ministry of Economic Planning and Development (MEPD), Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Public Enterprise Unit (PEU) on national budgeting leading to increased capacities for fiscal issues management in the country and preparation and presentation of the Paper entitled “Budget Deficit Financing: Challenges and Solutions for Swaziland” to the central ministries’ Principal Secretaries and Ministers in light of the fiscal issues; training for 11 Ministry of Economic Planning and Development (MEPD) Macro on the Threshold 21 (T21) leading to the incorporation of the SDG module in the version 3.5; Supported MEPD Poverty Unit staff on short-term M&E training in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

1. Increased policy research and knowledge building capacities for policy reform in prioritised national development areas: three (3) policy research assessments undertaken and subsequent consolidation of knowledge products into policy technical papers/ briefs for upstream engagement. 2. Policy Research Internship programme: Five (5) national research interns supported to conduct focused and prioritized studies. 3. Three (3) policy development interventions supported: Special Economic Zones, Water and Gender. 4. High level advisory services provided for analysis and information consolidation for socio-economic growth: Number of high level advisory notes developed.

1. Continued support for policy research and knowledge building capacities was enabled resulting in production of five (5) policy research study reports which were presented at the first Swaziland Economic Conference held 23-25 October 2017: Socio-economic of El-Nino-induced drought in Swaziland (IRRF 5.2); Shadow Economy; Mapping the National System of Innovation – Research and Development in Swaziland; Comparison of Hydroponics vs Soil Grown Vegetables: A Cost Benefit Analysis; and Assessing the impact of National Marketing Boards on Consumer and Producer Welfare. 2. Policy Research Internship programme in partnership with SEPARC assisted five (5) national research graduates receive mentoring and skills development for data mining, policy analysis and technical paper drafting and report writing. 3. Two (2) policy drafts were developed: Special Economic Zones Policy with the Ministry of Commerce Industry and Trade; and National Water Policy with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Energy. An additional instrument was also the development of the Special Economic Zones Bill through support from Mauritius. The development of the National Gender Policy was prioritized for 2018. 4. High level advisory services were provided for analysis on socio-economic growth: One high-level technical paper was produced for increased insights to the budgeting process for the 2016/2017 fiscal year. This assisted the Ministries of Economic Planning and Development and Finance with the fiscal consolidation. Five (5) policy briefs were produced to inform sectoral policy reform in disaster management, informal sector, agricultural productivity and innovation.

i. High-level technical and advisory services provided for analysis and information consolidation for socio-economic growth: Number of high level advisory notes developed.
ii. The National Water Policy, 2018 was approved by the Cabinet and under operationalization. The policy research and analysis partnership with SEPARC led to three (3) development investigations being completed together with policy briefs on trends analysis on inequalities opportunities in the education sector, and entrepreneurship credit facilities.
iii. The 2018 National Water Policy was approved by the Cabinet following a validation process by national stakeholders. This included intense engagement with various national stakeholders nation-wide in 2017.
1. The development of the National Gender Policy is underway, and the Inception Report has been produced.
Continued Partnerships with the Eswatini Economic Policy Analysis and Research Centre (ESEPARC) resulted in two (2) dialogues: The University of Eswatini (UNESWA) Faculty of Agriculture hosted the role of technology in agricultural production and food security; and ESEPARC facilitated the role of indigenous knowledge in sustainable development.
The CO disseminated the HDI Update which included engagement with the government, private sector and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).
iv. Policy Research Internship programme built capacities of three (3) national research interns on assessment, analytic tools, data collection and policy analysis. The training also included learning on the development of presentations as well as public speaking.
